title: Axed Sunday Night host Melissa Doyle will remain at Channel Seven
text:
Her long-running national current affairs show was axed this week.

But it seems Sunday Night host Melissa Doyle is set to remain with Channel Seven.

According to The Daily Telegraph, the 49-year-old is contracted to the network for another couple of years, and the former Sunrise host's services will be deployed elsewhere across their 2020 schedule.

Not going anywhere! According to The Daily Telegraph , the Melissa (pictured) is contracted to Channel Seven for another couple of years, and her services will be deployed elsewhere

On Wednesday, Craig McPherson, Channel Seven's director of news and public affairs, announced Sunday Night's closure, saying it was a 'very tough decision in a challenging TV landscape'.

'After 11 years at the forefront of our Public Affairs offering, it is with much sadness I announce the closing down of the day-to-day operations of Sunday Night: True Stories,' said Mr McPherson.

'I want to thank the exceptional team of reporters, producers, camera operators, editors and many others who have helped produce more than 500 hours of quality public affairs programming over its lifetime,' he added.

Bittersweet goodbye: 'After 11 years at the forefront of our Public Affairs offering, it is with much sadness I announce the closing down of the day-to-day operations of Sunday Night: True Stories,' said Craig McPherson, Channel Seven's director of news and public affairs

Mr McPherson confirmed Sunday Night will remain on air throughout 2019.

According to TV Tonight, the cancellation was part of a 'major overhaul' at the network to reduce costs.

The industry website reported Seven's new CEO James Warburton - who recently replaced Tim Worner - hopes 'to create a leaner and more agile company with a content-led strategy'.

Sunday Night, which debuted in 2009, has struggled for some time.

Industry insiders have said its recent declining ratings and expensive costs meant a cancellation was inevitable.

It has been rumoured Channel Seven was planning on bringing back weeknight current affairs show Today Tonight, which currently only airs in Adelaide and Perth.

On Friday, an unnamed network executive shot down the rumours, telling The Daily Telegraph: 'Today Tonight is not on the deck in any form'.

authors: Shannon Shipley For Daily Mail Australia
